questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is a nasal cannula. It delivers oxygen at 1-6 L/min.

questions.text: You are encountering a case at the forensics department where the victim's body had an entry wound from a shotgun as shown below. You would suspect that it was most likely shot at a distance range of ____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a central 'rat-hole' appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun which can be seen from 1 to 5 meters of range.

Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in the 30 cm to 1 m range.

Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in the 1 m to 5 m range.

The rat-hole appearance of the entry wound:

Appearance of shotgun entry wounds at different ranges:

Contact shot

  • Soft tissues - single circular wound about the diameter of the muzzle with muzzle imprint and no soot soiling, tattooing, singeing.
  • Bone - same as with soft tissues, but wound may be ragged and split because of gas rebound.

<30 cm

  • Circular wound with surrounding soot soiling.
  • Burnt hairs (singeing).
  • Punctate skin lesions from powder particles (tattooing).

30cm - 1m

  • Circular rat-hole wound.
  • Soot soiling.
  • Powder tattooing.

1 - 5 meters

  • Central rat-hole wound.
  • No soot, tattooing +/-.
  • Satellite pellet holes around the periphery.

>5 meters

  • Diffuse pellet pattern
  • No central hole, no soot soiling, tattooing, singeing.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man met with a road traffic accident and caused damage to public property while being drunk due to forced intoxication by his colleagues. In court, he can plead innocence based on which of the following sections?

BNS- Bharatiya Nayaya Sanhita; IPC - Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
Baseed on the vignette, he can plead innocence under BNS sec 23 (85 IPC)

It talks about the criminal responsibility of forceful intoxication, against a person's will or knowledge. It states that:

Nothing is an offense which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, is by reason of intoxication, incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong, or contrary to law; provided that the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will.

questions.text: A man comes to the emergency with a 0.5 cm deep clean lacerated wound on his forearm.  The suture technique shown below was used to close the wound. What should be the ideal distance between 2 consecutive sutures in this method?
questions.solution:
The above image shows simple interrupted sutures. While using this method, if 'x' is the depth of the wound, then the bite distance on each side of the incision must be 'x', while the distance between 2 consecutive sutures must be '2x'. Therefore, the distance between two consecutive sutures in this patient would be 2 * depth of the wound = 2 * 0.5 cm = 1 cm.

In interrupted sutures, the needle should enter and exit at right angles. The needle should be rotated through the tissue and should not be dragged through to avoid enlargement of the needle holes.

The image below shows the interrupted suturing technique.

Other commonly used suturing techniques include:

Mattress sutures - can either be vertical or horizontal. The initial suture is inserted as in an interrupted suture. The needle can then be moved either horizontally or vertically, traversing both edges of the wound once again.

The image below shows horizontal and vertical mattress sutures.

Continuous sutures - the first suture is inserted similar to an interrupted suture. The rest of the sutures are made in a continuous manner till the other end of the wound. 

The continuous suturing technique is shown below.

questions.text:
According to the National Immunization Schedule, what is the dose of vitamin A that should be administered with the first dose of the vaccine shown in the image?

IU- international units
questions.solution:
According to the national immunization schedule, 1 lakh IU of vitamin A should be given orally along with the first dose of the measles-rubella vaccine, which is shown in the image.

The first dose of the vaccine is given at 9 months of age. It can be given up to a maximum age of 5 years. It is given along with the measles vaccine as it enhances antibody production and confers sustained immunity against measles.

Vitamin A deficiency arises mostly due to its inadequate amounts in the diet. It can present as night blindness, conjunctival xerosis, Bitot's spots, and keratomalacia. At later stages, it can lead to xerophthalmia.

The image below shows Bitot's spots.

It also increases the risk of developing measles, diarrhea, and dysentery. Skin manifestations include xerosis, scaling, and dermomalacia. Phrynoderma may also be seen as keratotic follicular papules affecting the thighs and upper arms. It is shown in the image below.

In patients above the age of 1 year, vitamin A deficiency is treated with 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU by intramuscular route. It should be repeated the next day and four weeks later.

Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin, that plays an essential role in vision, reproduction, and maintenance of epithelial integrity. The various forms of vitamin A include retinol (storage form), retinal, retinoic acid, and beta-carotene. It is stored in the liver perisinusoidal stellate (Ito) cells as retinyl ester (retinol palmitate).

questions.text: Common carotid artery bifurcates at the level of _______.
questions.solution:
The bifurcation of the common carotid artery is at the upper border of the thyroid cartilage, at the level of the C3-C4 junction.

The course of the common carotid artery (CCA):

  • The right and the left common carotid arteries differ in their origin:
    • The right CCA arises from the brachiocephalic artery
    • The left CCA arises directly from the arch of the aorta
  • In the neck, it is enclosed within the carotid sheath along with the internal jugular vein and vagus nerve.
  • It ascends upwards up to the upper border of the thyroid cartilage (C3-4 junction) and divides into internal and external carotid arteries.

Clinical significance of carotid bifurcation:

  • Chassaignac/carotid tubercle/transverse process of C6 vertebra: The pulsations of the common carotid artery can be felt by compressing the artery against this tubercle. 
  • Site of carotid body tumor
  • The most common site for carotid atherosclerosis. It can lead to stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA).
  • In carotid endarterectomy, the presence of high bifurcation predisposes to injury to the cranial nerves, commonly the hypoglossal nerve or marginal mandibular nerve. In such patients, carotid stenting is usually preferred to carotid endarterectomy.

 

Carotid body tumors present at the bifurcation of the CCA and cause the external carotid artery (ECA) and internal carotid artery (ICA) to spread out, or splay, which is called 'Lyre sign' as seen on carotid angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following coagulation factors is directly responsible for the conversion of factor II to IIa in the extrinsic pathway?
questions.solution:
In both the intrinsic and the extrinsic pathways, factor Xa is responsible for the conversion of prothrombin (factor II) to thrombin (factor IIa).

Tissue factor is expressed on the surfaces of the subendothelial cellular components of the vessel wall, such as smooth muscle cells and fibroblasts. This tissue factor is exposed to blood when there is vascular damage. This activates the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, which is as follows:

  • Tissue factor binds with serine protease factor VIIa
  • This complex then activates factor IX to factor IXa
  • Factor IXa then activates factor X to factor Xa
  • Factor Xa can be formed through the actions of either the tissue factor-factor VIIa complex of factor IXa (with factor VIIIa as cofactor)
  • Factor Xa then converts prothrombin to thrombin, which is the pivotal protease of the coagulation cascade.
  • The cofactor essential for this conversion is factor Va.
  • The thrombin then formed converts the soluble plasma fibrinogen to an insoluble fibrin matrix.
  • Thrombin also activates factor XIII, which is the fibrin-stabilizing factor to factor XIIIa. This factor XIIIa forms covalent cross-links and thereby stabilizes the fibrin clot.

questions.text: An autopsy of a 65-year old man who passed away from complications due to myocardial infarction was conducted. The histopathological examination of the infarcted area of the heart revealed contraction band necrosis, nuclear pyknosis, and hypereosinophilia. After how much time will these findings occur after a myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
The histopathological findings of contraction band necrosis, nuclear pyknosis, and hypereosinophilia  are seen 12-24 hours after myocardial infarction.

Pathological contraction bands, also known as Zenker's necrosis, are a type of necrosis pattern found in the myocardium. Histologically, the pattern seen is hyper contraction and lysis of small groups of myocardial cells. Contraction bands are seen surrounding an acute myocardial infarction.

Other causes of contraction bands are:

  • Coronary occlusion
  • Resuscitation attempts
  • Drowning
  • Burning
  • Hypothermia.

Other changes that occur ar 12-24 hours are the gross appearance of dark mottling and microscopic features such as ongoing coagulative necrosis, and early neutrophilic infiltrate.

Other options:

Option A - Histopathological changes occurring by 7-10 days are well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells and the presence of granulation tissue at margins. On gross examination, it appears maximally yellow-tan and soft, with depressed red-tan margins.

Option B -Histopathological changes occurring by 10-14 days are well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition. On gross examination, it appears as red-gray depressed infarct borders.

Option C -Histopathological changes occurring by 4-12 hours are early coagulative necrosis, edema, and hemorrhage. On gross examination, there is occasional dark mottling.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
PaO2 /FiO2 ratio <300 mm Hg (not <375) is an indication of mechanical ventilation.

Indications of mechanical ventilation:

Directly measured indices

  • Arterial oxygen tension <50 mmHg on room air
  • Arterial CO2 tension >50 mmHg in the absence of metabolic alkalosis

Derived indices

  • PaO2 /FiO2 ratio <300 mm Hg
  • PA–aO2 gradient >350 mm Hg
  • Vd/Vt >0.6 (Ratio of physiologic dead space over tidal volume)

Clinical indices

  • Respiratory rate >35 breaths/min

Mechanical indices

  • Tidal volume <5 mL/kg
  • Vital capacity <15 mL/kg
  • Maximum inspiratory force > −25 cm H2O

questions.text: A researcher was conducting a study on the relationship between the bladder volume and perception of bladder fullness.  What quantity of urine is required to cause this marked sense of fullness?
questions.solution:
400 mL of urine in the bladder is required to cause this marked sense of fullness.

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL (option D).

The relationship between the intravesical pressure and volume of fluid in the bladder can be plotted in a graph and is studied by the cystometrogram.

The curve shows

  • An initial increase in pressure when there is a first increase in volume (Ia)
  • A long and flat portion which is produced with a further increase in volume (Ib);
  • A sudden, sharp increase in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered(II).
  • The law of Laplace explains the flatness of segment Ib. It states that the pressure in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension divided by the radius, P= 2T/R
  • In case of the blad­der, the filling of the bladder and the radius increases with increase in the tension. Therefore, there is slight increase in pressure increase until the organ is relatively full.

The below curve shows a cystometrogram.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman doing heavy work,  asks for your advice regarding the additional energy requirement while breastfeeding her 8-month-old child. What is the total calorie requirement per day in her case?
questions.solution:
The total calorie requirement per day for the woman is 3240 Kcal/day.

In the given scenario, the basal energy requirement for a woman doing heavy work is 2720 Kcal/day. When the woman is lactating the additional requirements per day are:

  • Lactation for 0-6 months = + 600 Kcal/day
  • Lactation for 7-12 months = + 520 Kcal/day

In this scenario, a heavy working woman is breastfeeding her 8 month old child, therefore an additional 520Kcal/day is required to the basal requirement of 2720 Kcal/day. This adds up to 3240 Kcal/day.

questions.text: A young woman was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. She opens her eyes to painful stimuli, but her speech is confused. She can localize pain on the right side, but withdraws from pain on the left side. What is her Glasgow Coma Scale score?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of the patient is 11 and her component score is E2V4M5.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury. It has three components: eye-opening, verbal, and motor abilities. Each component is assigned a score, and the total score is presented as a sum of three.

  • Eye-opening: To painful stimulus = 2 
  • Verbal response: Confused = 4
  • Motor response: Localize the pain on the right side = 5

In GCS, the best motor response elicited is considered for scoring. As seen in this patient, if she can localize the pain on the right side but withdraws from pain on the left side, then the motor component of the right side would be considered, and the score would be 5. Therefore, her component score would be E2V4M5 and adding 2+4+5 gives a score of 11.

A GCS score of <8 denotes severe brain injury.

  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: You are a resident doctor in the intensive care unit. You administer a drug 'X' to a patient. The plasma concentration of the drug reaches 500 mg/L. The drug follows zero-order kinetics. 200 mg of the drug 'X' is eliminated in 4 hours. What is the clearance of this drug?
questions.solution:
The clearance of drug X is 1.66 mL/min.

Since drug X follows zero-order kinetics, the elimination rate (amount of drug eliminated in unit time) is constant.

200 mg is eliminated in 4 hours. Therefore, 50 mg is eliminated in 1 hour as it follows zero-order kinetics.

Clearance = Rate of elimination/Plasma concentration

Rate of elimintation= 50 mg/h
Plasma concentration= 500 mg/L

Clearance = (50 mg/hr)/(500 mg/L)= 0.1 L/h

To convert L/h to mL/min, multiply by 1000 and divide by 60.

∴ Clearance = 0.1 x 1000 ml/60 min= 1.66 mL/min

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the heart rate in idioventricular rhythm?
questions.solution:
A heart rate of less than 40 beats/minute is consistent with idioventricular rhythm. 

Idioventricular rhythm occurs when both the sinoatrial node (SAN) and atrioventricular node (AVN) do not function. This leads to the Purkinje system taking over as a pacemaker to ensure ventricular contraction. The rate is usually less than 40 beats/minute. 

Causes of idioventricular rhythm include electrolyte abnormalities, digitoxin toxicity, anesthetic agents, cocaine, and isoprenaline. 

The usual findings of idioventricular rhythm include a heart rate of fewer than 40 beats per minute. The ECG may or may not have P waves. If there is a complete AVN block leading to sinus rhythm with idioventricular escape rhythm it will have P waves. Idioventricular rhythm without P waves is of poor prognosis. This usually proceeds a flat line. 

Other options: 

Option A - A heart rate of more than 300 beats/minute is seen in atrial flutter.

Option C - A heart rate of 50 - 100 beats per minute is seen in normal sinus rhythm and accelerated idioventricular rhythm.

Option A - A heart rate of more than 100 beats/ minute is seen in sinus tachycardia and non-sustained ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: Detection of products of dead cells by inflammasome induces secretion of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Detection of products of dead cells by inflammasome induces secretion of interleukin-1 (IL-1).

Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators. 

Apoptosis: The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9, whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3 and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclei fragmentation.

Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent distinct pathway of cell death induced by lipid peroxidation. The widespread peroxidation disrupts membrane function, which leads to the loss of plasma membrane permeability and results in cell death resembling necrosis. 

Necroptosis, as the name suggests, has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis. This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death.

questions.text:
What is the qSOFA score in a patient whose examination findings are as shown below?
  • GCS - 13/15
  • RR - 26/min
  • Pulse - 112/min
  • BP - 96/62 mm Hg
  • SpO2 - 89%
  • Abdomen - soft, nontender
questions.solution:
qSOFA score for this patient would be 3. Only 3 parameters are considered for its calculation, and the respective scores are as follows:

  • BP: 96/62 mmHg → Low blood pressure (SBP ≤100 mmHg) → Score 1
  • Respiratory rate: 26 breaths/min → High (≥22 breaths/min) → Score 1
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score: 13/15 → Altered mentation (GCS score, <15) → Score 1

qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU). It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

  • low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg),
  • high respiratory rate (≥22 breaths/min)
  • altered mentation (Glasgow Coma Scale score, <15).

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis. This is a simplified derivative of SOFA score. The primary method to evaluate the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspected infection is by determining the  Sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment (SOFA) score; which includes assessment of:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors; platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow Coma Scale score 
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin level
  • Renal function - Creatinine level

Organ dysfunction is defined by a SOFA score of ≥2.

The SOFA score is limited by its requirement of multiple laboratory tests which makes it complex and time-consuming. In order to simplify the scoring process, the "Sepsis - 3" task force recommended the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score.

SOFA vs. qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system, which is particulary superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting. 
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment of individuals at risk for sepsis particularly useful outside the ICU. setting (i.e. ward / emergency department). However, note that it was originally designed as predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

Thereby, the best description of sepsis based on "Sepsis -3" task force recommendations would be as follows:

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score of ≥2  Or
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score of ≥2

Another score that has been used is the National Early Warning Score (NEWS). It ranges from 0 to 20 and is based on respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, use of supplemental O2, temperature, systolic blood pressure, pulse rate, and level of consciousness. ≥5 out of 20 is considered a positive score. 

Other scoring systems for sepsis:

The Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) score is no longer recommended as is it not specific to infection.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: A child is brought to a pediatrician for a regular check-up. He observed that the child could run stiffly, crawl up or downstairs, scribble, and build a tower of 3 blocks. What could be the possible age of the child?
questions.solution:
The child is possibly 18 months old.

At age 18 months, the child the milestones attained by the child are:

  • Motor:
    • Run
    • Crawl up and downstairs
    • Explore drawers and wastebasket
  • Adaptive:
    • Make a tower of 3-4 blocks
    • Can scribble
  • Language:
    • Name pictures
    • Identify 1 or more parts of the body
    • A vocabulary of around 10 words
  • Social:
    • Feed themselves
    • Seek help when in trouble
    • May complain when wet or soiled

Other options:

Option B- At 24 months of age, the child can run well, walk up and down the stairs one step at a time, jump. He would be able to build a tower of 6-7 cubes and make circular strokes. He can make 3-word sentences. 

Option C- At 12 months, the child walks with one hand-held, has a mature pincer grasp, and can say 1-2 words with meaning. He may be able to play a simple ball game.

Option D- At 30 months, the child can climb stairs with alternating feet, and build a tower of 9 cubes. He can copy a circle. He knows his full name, and refers to himself as "I".

questions.text: Which of the following pharyngeal arches gives rise to paired hyaline laryngeal cartilage?
questions.solution:
The 6th pharyngeal arch gives rise to the arytenoid cartilage which is a hyaline type of paired laryngeal cartilage. 

The laryngeal cavity consists of 6 cartilages, which are classified into two types: paired and unpaired. The paired cartilages include arytenoid, corniculate and cuneiform. Among these, only arytenoid is the hyaline type, while corniculate and cuneiform are the elastic types.

questions.text: At what age of gestation is an amniocentesis generally done?
questions.solution:
The best time for performing amniocentesis is 15-20 weeks of gestation

Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure. It is performed using an aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle. The needle is directed perpendicularly into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord. Sonography is used to observe the uterine puncture site for bleeding and fetal cardiac motion is documented at the end of the procedure. Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping or chromosomal microarray analysis. 

Study material

Amniotic fluid with amniocytes

Time

15-20 weeks

Early amniocentesis

11-14 weeks (associated with increased fetal loss, foot deformities)

Indications
  • Congenital infections
  • Fetal genetic disorders
  • Alloimmunization
Complications
  • Fetal loss
  • Amniotic fluid leakage
  • Transvaginal spotting

Below is an image showing the procedure of amniocentesis vs chorionic villus sampling.

Note:

Amniocentesis is generally done between 15-20 weeks but may be performed at any point later in gestation.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester
